questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is defined as loss of eyelashes?
questions.explanation:
Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows. • Loss of eyebrows is seen in leprosy and myxedema. • Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis. Other options: Option A: Tylosis is a thickening of the tarsal border of the eyelid. Option C: Trichiasis is an inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin. 374 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Distichiasis is the presence of a double row of eyelashes.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the term used to describe an extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line?
questions.explanation:
The extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called distichiasis. Distichiasis can occur due to congenital or acquired causes. These lashes may irritate the cornea. 
Management is by lid splitting with cryotherapy to the base of the hair follicles. Other options: Option A: Trichiasis is inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin. Option C: Tylosis is the thickening of the tarsal plate. Option D: Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows. 375 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A term neonate is referred to the district hospital for an ophthalmic exam. Partial fusion of 
her right upper and lower eyelids by a central narrow band of tissue is noted as shown below. 
The left eye examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? 365 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows an adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids, which 
suggests ankyloblepharon. It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, 
ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Treatment is the excision of the adhesions 
between lid margins. In severe cases where the adhesions involve the angle of the eyes, epithelial 
grafts can be used. Other options: Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, whereby 
the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball. Option C: Blepharophimosis is a congenital anomaly in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is 
decreased. It appears contracted at the outer canthus. 376 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Lagophthalmos is characterized by the inability to close the eyelids voluntarily. It may 
be due to a malfunction of the facial nerve. The image below shows nocturnal lagophthalmos 
(inability to close eyelids during sleep).

questions.question:
Question 4: A male patient complains of a foreign body sensation, irritation, and lacrimation in the right 
eye. During the evaluation, you notice the following findings with normal lid margins. What is 
this condition known as?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the above image is suggestive of trichiasis. Trichiasis refers to the inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the 
normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensations and 
photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation. On examination, one 
or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea are seen. The conjunctiva may be congested. Treatment includes: 377 
Sold by @itachibot • Epilation: Mechanical removal with forceps • Electrolysis: Method of destroying the lash follicle by electric current. • Cryoepilation • Surgical correction.

questions.question: Question 5: What defines telecanthus?

options.d: Widened root of the nose with normal inter-pupillary distance

questions.explanation:
Telecanthus means an increased distance between medial canthi (widened root of the nose) with 
normal inter-pupillary distance. In hypertelorism, there is a wide bony separation of the orbits. In epicanthus, there are bilateral vertical folds of skin that extend from the upper or lower lids 
towards the medial canthi. They may give rise to pseudoesotropia. 378 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Weiss operation is done in which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Weiss operation is done in senile entropion. In this operation, the transverse lid split, and 
everything sutures are placed. Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more 
common in the lower lid. Causes include: • Horizontal lid laxity • Vertical lid instability • Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure • Orbital septum laxity

questions.question: Question 7: For which of the following is medial conjunctivoplasty the surgical modality of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Medial conjunctivoplasty is done in involutional ectropion. Ectropion is the eversion of the lid margin and eyelashes away from the globe. Types: • Involutional/senile - affects the lower lid of elderly patients. • Cicatricial - caused by the scarring or contracture of the skin and underlying tissues • Paralytic - caused by ipsilateral facial nerve palsy • Mechanical - caused by tumors on or near the lid margin that mechanically evert the lid 379 
Sold by @itachibot • Congenital

questions.question: Question 8: Which among the following is not a feature of blepharophimosis syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Entropion is not a feature of blepharophimosis syndrome. Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) consists of the following: • Narrow palpebral fissure • Ptosis • Congenital ectropion of the lower lid • Telecanthus • Epicanthus inversus: an extra fold of skin arising from the lower lid The image below shows blepharophimosis. 380 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye 
exam. Which of the following pair of muscles are likely to be affected in this patient?

options.b: Levator palpebrae superioris and superior oblique
options.d: Levator palpebrae superioris and Muller's muscle

questions.explanation:
The patient has mild right eye ptosis. Injury or weakness of levator palpebrae superioris and 
Muller's muscle leads to ptosis. Levator palpebrae superioris is the important upper eyelid retractor. Frontalis and Muller’s 
muscle assist in the elevation of the upper eyelid.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following conditions is a cause of pseudoptosis?
questions.explanation:
Brow ptosis is a type of pseudoptosis, not ptosis. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the 
superior cornea. Types of ptosis: • Mechanical ptosis - Can be due to lid tumors, multiple/big chalazions, and conjunctival scarring • Aponeurotic ptosis - Due to dehiscence of the aponeurosis and in postoperative patients • Involutional ptosis seen in old age • Neurogenic ptosis due to a 3rd nerve palsy, Horner syndrome and synkinetic 
ptosis/Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking ptosis • Myogenic ptosis • Congenital: most common myogenic ptosis • Simple • Blepharophimosis syndrome • Congenital synkinetic ptosis 381 
Sold by @itachibot • Acquired • Myasthenia gravis • Lambert–Eaton syndrome • Ocular myopathy Causes of pseudoptosis (apparent ptosis): • Lack of support of the lids by the globe e.g. artificial eye, microphthalmos, phthisis bulbi, or 
enophthalmos. • Contralateral lid retraction • Ipsilateral hypotropia • Brow ptosis occurs due to excessive skin on the brow, or seventh nerve palsy, which is diagnosed 
by manually elevating the eyebrow • Dermatochalasis

questions.question:
Question 11: 368 
Sold by @itachibot A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. 
He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most 
common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and ptosis is the most common 
ocular feature of the disease. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most 
commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by 
weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated 
use and may improve following rest. Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints due to early involvement of the lids and 
extraocular muscles (EOMs). Of them, Ptosis is a more common manifestation than diplopia. 
Ptosis in myasthenia gravis is insidious, bilateral, and frequently asymmetrical. Investigations of myasthenia gravis include: • Ice pack test -This tests for a transient improvement of the ptotic eyelid on placing an ice pack 
for 2 minutes, as the cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase. • Tensilon (Edrophonium) test - This tests for a transient improvement in the weakness on 
administration of a short-acting anticholinesterase such as edrophonium. • Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps 
support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following conditions will not have a finding of bilateral ptosis?
questions.explanation:
Bilateral ptosis is not seen in Marfan's syndrome. Causes of unilateral ptosis: 382 
Sold by @itachibot • Horner's syndrome • Oculomotor nerve palsy Causes of bilateral ptosis: • Congenital • Senile/involutional/aponeurotic • Blepharophimosis syndrome • Myasthenia gravis • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) - seen in Kearns-Sayre syndrome • Myotonic dystrophy • Ocular myopathies The image below shows a case of botulinum toxicity with bilateral ptosis.

questions.question:
Question 13: During OPD hours, a patient came with the finding shown below. On examination, the upper 
4 mm of the cornea is covered by the upper eyelid. What is the grade of ptosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In this question, 4 mm of the cornea is covered by the upper eyelid. Subtracting 2 mm from this 
implies that there is 2 mm of ptosis, which is classified as mild grade. In bilateral cases, the grade of ptosis can be determined by measuring the amount of cornea 
covered by the upper lid and then subtracting 2 mm. Depending upon this value, the ptosis is 
graded as follows: • Mild: 2 mm • Moderate: 3 mm • Severe: 4 mm 383 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A child with a high risk of amblyopia is planned for surgical correction of unilateral simple 
congenital ptosis. He has poor levator function. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.explanation:
Frontalis sling procedure is the treatment of choice for congenital ptosis with poor levator 
function.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis 
along with mild ptosis. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing a Fasanella-Servat 
operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in 
this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller's muscle. Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller's muscle. Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(< 2 mm) and good levator 
function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and 
conjunctiva are resected.

questions.question:
Question 16: A couple brought their 11-month-old child for an eye exam when they noticed that his left 
upper eyelid was in a lower position than his right one. The mother also noticed that his left 
upper eyelid goes "up and down” when she breastfeeds him. His delivery was unremarkable. 
When the baby opens his mouth or sucks his thumb, the left eyelid ptosis disappears. What is 
the pathology behind this condition?

options.a: Superior division of the third cranial nerve is misdirected
options.b: Sympathetic nerves to Muller's muscles are misdirected
options.c: Ophthalmic division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected
options.d: Mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. In this 
condition, the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle. Some cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. 
The vast majority are unilateral. Signs include retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with 
stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or 
contralateral jaw movement. Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, 
swallowing, and clenching of teeth. Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may 
learn to mask it. The following image shows a woman with Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. See how her 
right eyelid ptosis retracts with the opening of the mouth. 384 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is the causative agent for blepharitis acarica?
questions.explanation:
Blepharitis acarica is caused by Demodex folliculorum. Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the margins of the lids. The two types are • Anterior • Seborrheic and ulcerative types • Caused by staphylococci, mainly • Posterior – Mebomianitis Occasionally caused by • Demodex folliculorum – Blepharitis acarica • Crab louse – Phthiriasis palpebrarum The following image shows swollen and inflamed eyelid suggestive of blepharitis. 385 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: What is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelid?
questions.explanation:
Basal cell carcinoma constitutes 85–90% of all malignant epithelial eyelid tumors. It is locally 
malignant and most commonly involves the lower lid, followed by the medial canthus, upper lid, 
and outer canthus. Type 
Common location 
Clinical features

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following systemic drugs is used specifically in the management of periocular 
basal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Vismodegib is the systemic drug used for the management of periocular basal cell carcinoma 
(BCC). Vismodegib is an eye-sparing adjuvant therapy of periocular and orbital BCC for patients: • Who cannot tolerate surgery or radiotherapy, or • With relapsed locally advanced disease after surgery or 386 
Sold by @itachibot • With metastatic disease. Vismodegib is a Hedgehog pathway inhibitor, given 150 mg orally twice a day. Treatment options for BCC consist of surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. Surgical excision 
using Mohs micrographic surgery or wide surgical excision with frozen section margin control is 
the first-line treatment of periocular BCC. Other options: Option A: Imiquimod 5% topical cream can also be used in patients with BCC. But, it is not a 
systemic drug. Option C: Siponimod is the drug approved for secondary progressive multiple sclerosis. Option D: Interferons are generally not used in periocular BCC.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 6-month-old girl was brought by her worried parents due to a swelling on the eyelid as 
shown below. They were told by a local village doctor that the swelling will disappear on its 
own but recently it has been increasing rapidly. What would be the most likely management 
of this baby's condition? 371 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Treatment with intralesional steroids at 2 years of age

questions.explanation:
The history and image are suggestive of capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and 
periocular region causing severe mechanical ptosis. Immediate management with oral propranolol 
is the treatment of choice in this case. The ptosis is so severe that it obstructs the pupillary area (visual axis) with the risk of sensory 
deprivation amblyopia. This warrants immediate treatment to reduce the bulk of the tumor. Capillary hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often. It may be managed by oral 
propranolol, oral prednisolone, or intralesional steroid. Indications for treatment of patients with capillary hemangioma with pharmacologic therapy are: • Visual symptoms (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus) • Cosmesis • Optic nerve compression • Exposure keratopathy

questions.question: Question 21: Identify the clinical condition.
questions.explanation:
The image shows plexiform neurofibroma of the upper lid causing an S-shaped deformity of the 
upper lid and mechanical ptosis. This is seen particularly in neurofibromatosis type 1. NF1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on 
chromosome 17. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS 
regulator. The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following seven features are 
present: • Six or more café-au-lait macules (CALMs) - They are the hallmark of neurofibromatosis and are 
present in almost 100% of patients. They are present at birth but increase in size, number, and 
pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life, and are scattered over the entire body. • Axillary or inguinal freckling 387 
Sold by @itachibot • Two or more iris Lisch nodules - They are iris hamartomas that are best identified by a slit-lamp 
examination. They are present in the majority of patients with NF1. • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones such as 
the tibia • Optic gliomas (most frequently observed CNS tumor in NF1) • A first-degree relative with NF-1

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following sign is used to describe the fullness of eyelids seen in Grave's 
ophthalmopathy?

options.a: It needs to be surgically treated.
options.c: It does not have malignant potential.
options.d: It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.explanation:
The fullness of the eyelids is described as the Enroth's sign in Graves ophthalmopathy. 388 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of Lacrimal Apparatus and Glands of the Eye
